citation.article-title: Desulfomonile tiedjei gen. nov. and sp. nov., a novel anaerobic, dehalogenating, sulfate-reducing bacterium.

p.s: Description of Desulfomonile gen. nov.
Desulfomonile (De-sul-fo-mo-ni-le, L. pref. de from; L.n. sulfur sulfur; L.n. monile collar; M.L. neut. n. Desulfomonile a "collared" sulfate-reducer)
We propose that the anaerobic, dehalogenating, sulfate-reducing bacterium strain DCB-I be placed in a new genus Desulfomonile.
The type species for this genus is D. tiedjei sp. nov., named to recognize the contributions of James M.
Tiedje and his laboratory to the field of microbial ecology.
A combined generic and specific description follows.
Rod-shaped cells 0.8-1 by 5-10 μm, with rounded ends, an invagination of the cell wall (collar) likely involved in binary fission, single.
Non-motile and no spore formation.
Gram negative.
Esculin negative.
Strict anaerobic chemoorganotroph or autotroph, which can grow in mineral medium with 1 mM Na2S⋄9 H2O or 0.5 mM Na2S2O4 as reductants.
Thiamine, nicotinamide and 1,4-naphthoquinone are required as growth factors.
Pyruvate is used as a carbon source and an electron donor and is converted to acetate and lactate.
Sulfate, sulfite, thiosulfate, and meta-halobenzoates can serve as electron acceptors and are reduced to H2S and benzoates, respectively.
L-Lactate, butyrate or acetate are poor substrates for growth with thiosulfate as the electron acceptor.
Benzoate, formate or H2 and CO2 can serve as carbon source and electron donors with sulfate or thiosulfate as the electron acceptor.
3-Anisate, 4-anisate, vanillate, isovanillate can serve as carbon sources with a slight stimulation of growth occurring if sulfate or thiosulfate are also present.
The pH range for growth is 6.5-7.8 and optimum at 6.8 - 7.0.
Temperature range is 30-38°C and optimum is 37°C.
Cells contain 97 μg⋄g-1 wet weight of PHB and also contain desulfoviridin and cytochrome c3.
The G + C content of the DNA is 49.0 mol% (Stevens et al. 1988).
The type strain Desulfomonile tiedjei strain DCB-1, ATCC 49306, was isolated from a sewage sludge bacterial consortium enriched on 3-chlorobenzoate as the sole carbon and energy source.
